Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Political Science: Accountability, Presidential Power, and the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to analyze the implementation of legislation. To implement a law, administrative agencies pass their own policies in order to fill in details not specified by the law. A major question in the study of democratic accountability is how agencies are held accountable and whose interests are reflected in the ways laws are implemented. The Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (OIRA) is responsible for carrying out this review process.

The intellectual merit of this project is associated with its study of an agency whose processes have not yet been subjected to systematic analysis. The purpose of this project is to analyze when, why, and how the review process is used. The primary research task is to compile a new dataset of all policymaking by agencies, indicating which policies were chosen for review and the outcome of review. To compile this dataset, OIRA's yearly summary documents and requests will be coded alongside more detailed information regarding exchanges between OIRA and agencies. The new data on instances of OIRA review will be combined with existing data on all agency policymaking from 1983-2010. When complete, the dataset of all policymaking, which includes both policies reviewed and not reviewed by OIRA, will permit an analysis of when, why, and how the review process is used.

The broader impacts of the project are associated with its research output and training components. The project will advance our understanding of the implementation of laws which, in turn, influences the opportunities of underrepresented groups. Further, the project will involve the training of undergraduate students in the research process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project set out to systematically analyze the U.S. president’s Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (OIRA), the most important innovation in presidential power in 35 years. OIRA reviews, and can attempt to change, agency policies before they are finalized.

This project is situated within a broader effort to better understand how presidents pursue policy outside of the legislative process, an especially important topic given gridlock in Congress. To this broader literature, I have contributed a new theory of U.S. presidents pursuing policy in the executive branch. Prior to this, studies have focused on presidents’ work to veto agency policy-making they dislike. Research on presidents proactively pursuing policy has been sparse and has focused on executive orders. Yet we know little beyond this initial, direction-setting step. I broaden these existing theories to account for presidents’ work to strengthen the policy-making they favor. My approach is simple but it has broad implications for how we think about, and how we research, the U.S. presidency: presidents pursue policy by strengthening agency policy-making they favor and by vetoing agency policy-making they are against. I formalize this theory as one contribution of the project.

In addition to this broad theoretical contribution, I contribute an empirical finding specific to OIRA that supports my theory. I collected an original data set spanning three presidential administrations: Presidents Clinton, George W. Bush, and Obama. I show Presidents Clinton and Obama were disproportionately likely to use OIRA with more liberal agencies (such as the Environmental Protection Agency), whereas President George W. Bush was disproportionately likely to use OIRA with more conservative agencies (such as the Small Business Administration). This finding differs from the conventional wisdom that OIRA is a presidential watchdog and it changes how we think about presidential power in administrative oversight. Future work on OIRA will need to account for presidents’ incentives to strengthen policies they like, not just veto ones they dislike.
